trans-unit.source: How to use Service Bus topics (Ruby) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use Service Bus topics (Ruby) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Service Bus topics and subscriptions in Azure. Code samples are written for Ruby applications.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Service Bus topics and subscriptions in Azure. Code samples are written for Ruby applications.

trans-unit.source: This guide will show you how to use Service Bus topics and subscriptions from Ruby applications.
trans-unit.target: This guide will show you how to use Service Bus topics and subscriptions from Ruby applications.

trans-unit.source: The scenarios covered include creating topics and subscriptions, creating subscription filters, sending messages to a topic, receiving messages from a subscription, and deleting topics and subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: The scenarios covered include creating topics and subscriptions, creating subscription filters, sending messages to a topic, receiving messages from a subscription, and deleting topics and subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: For more information on topics and subscriptions, see the <linkText>Next Steps</linkText><title></title> section.
trans-unit.target: For more information on topics and subscriptions, see the <linkText>Next Steps</linkText><title></title> section.

trans-unit.source: Service Bus topics and subscriptions support a publish/subscribe messaging communication model.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus topics and subscriptions support a publish/subscribe messaging communication model.

trans-unit.source: When using topics and subscriptions, components of a distributed application do not communicate directly with each other, they instead exchange messages via a topic, which acts as an intermediary.
trans-unit.target: When using topics and subscriptions, components of a distributed application do not communicate directly with each other, they instead exchange messages via a topic, which acts as an intermediary.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>TopicConcepts</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>TopicConcepts</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In contrast to Service Bus queues, where each message is processed by a single consumer, topics and subscriptions provide a one-to-many form of communication, using a publish/subscribe pattern.
trans-unit.target: In contrast to Service Bus queues, where each message is processed by a single consumer, topics and subscriptions provide a one-to-many form of communication, using a publish/subscribe pattern.

trans-unit.source: It is possible to register multiple subscriptions to a topic.
trans-unit.target: It is possible to register multiple subscriptions to a topic.

trans-unit.source: When a message is sent to a topic, it is then made available to each subscription to handle/process independently.
trans-unit.target: When a message is sent to a topic, it is then made available to each subscription to handle/process independently.

trans-unit.source: A topic subscription resembles a virtual queue that receives copies of the messages that were sent to the topic.
trans-unit.target: A topic subscription resembles a virtual queue that receives copies of the messages that were sent to the topic.

trans-unit.source: You can optionally register filter rules for a topic on a per-subscription basis, which allows you to filter/restrict which messages to a topic are received by which topic subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: You can optionally register filter rules for a topic on a per-subscription basis, which allows you to filter/restrict which messages to a topic are received by which topic subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: Service Bus topics and subscriptions enable you to scale to process a very large number of messages across a very large number of users and applications.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus topics and subscriptions enable you to scale to process a very large number of messages across a very large number of users and applications.

trans-unit.source: To begin using Service Bus queues in Azure, you must first create a service namespace.
trans-unit.target: To begin using Service Bus queues in Azure, you must first create a service namespace.

trans-unit.source: A service namespace provides a scoping container for addressing Service Bus resources within your application.
trans-unit.target: A service namespace provides a scoping container for addressing Service Bus resources within your application.

trans-unit.source: You must create the namespace through the command-line interface because the Portal does not create the service bus with an ACS connection.
trans-unit.target: You must create the namespace through the command-line interface because the Portal does not create the service bus with an ACS connection.

trans-unit.source: To create a namespace:
trans-unit.target: To create a namespace:

trans-unit.source: Open an Azure Powershell console.
trans-unit.target: Open an Azure Powershell console.

trans-unit.source: Type the command to create an Azure service bus namespace as shown below.
trans-unit.target: Type the command to create an Azure service bus namespace as shown below.

trans-unit.source: Provide your own namespace value and specify the same region as your application.
trans-unit.target: Provide your own namespace value and specify the same region as your application.

trans-unit.source: New-AzureSBNamespace -Name 'yourexamplenamespace' -Location 'West US' -NamespaceType 'Messaging' -CreateACSNamespace $true
trans-unit.target: New-AzureSBNamespace -Name 'yourexamplenamespace' -Location 'West US' -NamespaceType 'Messaging' -CreateACSNamespace $true

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create Namespace</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create Namespace</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In order to perform management operations, such as creating a queue on the new namespace, you must obtain the management credentials for the namespace.
trans-unit.target: In order to perform management operations, such as creating a queue on the new namespace, you must obtain the management credentials for the namespace.

trans-unit.source: The PowerShell cmdlet you ran to create the Azure service bus namespace displays the key you can use to manage the namespace.
trans-unit.target: The PowerShell cmdlet you ran to create the Azure service bus namespace displays the key you can use to manage the namespace.

trans-unit.source: Copy the DefaultKey value.
trans-unit.target: Copy the DefaultKey value.

trans-unit.source: You will use this value in your code later in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: You will use this value in your code later in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: You can also find this key if you log on to the <linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title> and navigate to the connection information for your service bus namespace.
trans-unit.target: You can also find this key if you log on to the <linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title> and navigate to the connection information for your service bus namespace.

trans-unit.source: Create a Ruby application.
trans-unit.target: Create a Ruby application.

trans-unit.source: For instructions, see <linkText>Create a Ruby Application on Azure</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For instructions, see <linkText>Create a Ruby Application on Azure</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To use Azure service bus, you need to download and use the Ruby azure package, which includes a set of convenience libraries that communicate with the storage REST services.
trans-unit.target: To use Azure service bus, you need to download and use the Ruby azure package, which includes a set of convenience libraries that communicate with the storage REST services.

trans-unit.source: Use a command-line interface such as PowerShell (Windows), Terminal (Mac), or Bash (Unix).
trans-unit.target: Use a command-line interface such as PowerShell (Windows), Terminal (Mac), or Bash (Unix).

trans-unit.source: Type "gem install azure" in the command window to install the gem and dependencies.
trans-unit.target: Type "gem install azure" in the command window to install the gem and dependencies.

trans-unit.source: Use your favorite text editor, add the following to the top of the Ruby file where you intend to use storage:
trans-unit.target: Use your favorite text editor, add the following to the top of the Ruby file where you intend to use storage:

trans-unit.source: The azure module will read the environment variables AZURE\_SERVICEBUS\_NAMESPACE and AZURE\_SERVICEBUS\_ACCESS\_KEY for information required to connect to your Azure service bus namespace.
trans-unit.target: The azure module will read the environment variables AZURE\_SERVICEBUS\_NAMESPACE and AZURE\_SERVICEBUS\_ACCESS\_KEY for information required to connect to your Azure service bus namespace.

trans-unit.source: If these environment variables are not set, you must specify the namespace information before using Azure::ServiceBusService with the following code:
trans-unit.target: If these environment variables are not set, you must specify the namespace information before using Azure::ServiceBusService with the following code:

trans-unit.source: Set the service bus namespace value to the value you created rather than the entire URL.
trans-unit.target: Set the service bus namespace value to the value you created rather than the entire URL.

trans-unit.source: For example, use "yourexamplenamespace", not "yourexamplenamespace.servicebus.windows.net".
trans-unit.target: For example, use "yourexamplenamespace", not "yourexamplenamespace.servicebus.windows.net".

trans-unit.source: The Azure::ServiceBusService object lets you work with topics.
trans-unit.target: The Azure::ServiceBusService object lets you work with topics.

trans-unit.source: The following code creates an Azure::ServiceBusService object.
trans-unit.target: The following code creates an Azure::ServiceBusService object.

trans-unit.source: To create a topic, use the create\_topic() method.
trans-unit.target: To create a topic, use the create\_topic() method.

trans-unit.source: The following example creates a topic or print out the error if there is any.
trans-unit.target: The following example creates a topic or print out the error if there is any.

trans-unit.source: You can also pass in a Azure::ServiceBus::Topic object with additional options, which allows you to override default topic settings such as message time to live or maximum queue size.
trans-unit.target: You can also pass in a Azure::ServiceBus::Topic object with additional options, which allows you to override default topic settings such as message time to live or maximum queue size.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows setting the maximum queue size to 5GB and time to live to 1 minute:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows setting the maximum queue size to 5GB and time to live to 1 minute:

trans-unit.source: Topic subscriptions are also created with the Azure::ServiceBusService object.
trans-unit.target: Topic subscriptions are also created with the Azure::ServiceBusService object.

trans-unit.source: Subscriptions are named and can have an optional filter that restricts the set of messages delivered to the subscription's virtual queue.
trans-unit.target: Subscriptions are named and can have an optional filter that restricts the set of messages delivered to the subscription's virtual queue.

trans-unit.source: Subscriptions are persistent and will continue to exist until either they, or the topic they are associated with, are deleted.
trans-unit.target: Subscriptions are persistent and will continue to exist until either they, or the topic they are associated with, are deleted.

trans-unit.source: If your application contains logic to create a subscription, it should first check if the subscription already exists by using the getSubscription method.
trans-unit.target: If your application contains logic to create a subscription, it should first check if the subscription already exists by using the getSubscription method.

trans-unit.source: The MatchAll filter is the default filter that is used if no filter is specified when a new subscription is created.
trans-unit.target: The MatchAll filter is the default filter that is used if no filter is specified when a new subscription is created.

trans-unit.source: When the MatchAll filter is used, all messages published to the topic are placed in the subscription's virtual queue.
trans-unit.target: When the MatchAll filter is used, all messages published to the topic are placed in the subscription's virtual queue.

trans-unit.source: The following example creates a subscription named "all-messages" and uses the default MatchAll filter.
trans-unit.target: The following example creates a subscription named "all-messages" and uses the default MatchAll filter.

trans-unit.source: You can also setup filters that allow you to scope which messages sent to a topic should show up within a specific topic subscription.
trans-unit.target: You can also setup filters that allow you to scope which messages sent to a topic should show up within a specific topic subscription.

trans-unit.source: The most flexible type of filter supported by subscriptions is the Azure::ServiceBus::SqlFilter, which implements a subset of SQL92.
trans-unit.target: The most flexible type of filter supported by subscriptions is the Azure::ServiceBus::SqlFilter, which implements a subset of SQL92.

trans-unit.source: SQL filters operate on the properties of the messages that are published to the topic.
trans-unit.target: SQL filters operate on the properties of the messages that are published to the topic.

trans-unit.source: For more details about the expressions that can be used with a SQL filter, review the <linkText>SqlFilter.SqlExpression</linkText><title></title> syntax.
trans-unit.target: For more details about the expressions that can be used with a SQL filter, review the <linkText>SqlFilter.SqlExpression</linkText><title></title> syntax.

trans-unit.source: Filters can be added to a subscription by using the create\_rule() method of the Azure::ServiceBusService object.
trans-unit.target: Filters can be added to a subscription by using the create\_rule() method of the Azure::ServiceBusService object.

trans-unit.source: This method allows you to add new filters to an existing subscription.
trans-unit.target: This method allows you to add new filters to an existing subscription.

trans-unit.source: Since the default filter is applied automatically to all new subscriptions, you must first remove the default filter or the MatchAll will override any other filters you may specify.
trans-unit.target: Since the default filter is applied automatically to all new subscriptions, you must first remove the default filter or the MatchAll will override any other filters you may specify.

trans-unit.source: You can remove the default rule by using the delete\_rule() method of the Azure::ServiceBusService object.
trans-unit.target: You can remove the default rule by using the delete\_rule() method of the Azure::ServiceBusService object.

trans-unit.source: The examples below creates a subscription named "high-messages" with a Azure::ServiceBus::SqlFilter that only selects messages that have a custom message\_number property greater than 3:
trans-unit.target: The examples below creates a subscription named "high-messages" with a Azure::ServiceBus::SqlFilter that only selects messages that have a custom message\_number property greater than 3:

trans-unit.source: Similarly, the following example creates a subscription named "low-messages" with a Azure::ServiceBus::SqlFilter that only selects messages that have a message_number property less than or equal to 3:
trans-unit.target: Similarly, the following example creates a subscription named "low-messages" with a Azure::ServiceBus::SqlFilter that only selects messages that have a message_number property less than or equal to 3:

trans-unit.source: When a message is now sent to "test-topic", it will always be delivered to receivers subscribed to the "all-messages" topic subscription, and selectively delivered to receivers subscribed to the "high-messages" and "low-messages" topic subscriptions (depending upon the message content).
trans-unit.target: When a message is now sent to "test-topic", it will always be delivered to receivers subscribed to the "all-messages" topic subscription, and selectively delivered to receivers subscribed to the "high-messages" and "low-messages" topic subscriptions (depending upon the message content).

trans-unit.source: To send a message to a Service Bus topic, your application must use the send\_topic\_message() method of the Azure::ServiceBusService object.
trans-unit.target: To send a message to a Service Bus topic, your application must use the send\_topic\_message() method of the Azure::ServiceBusService object.

trans-unit.source: Messages sent to Service Bus Topics are Azure::ServiceBus::BrokeredMessage objects.
trans-unit.target: Messages sent to Service Bus Topics are Azure::ServiceBus::BrokeredMessage objects.

trans-unit.source: Azure::ServiceBus::BrokeredMessage objects have a set of standard properties (such as label and time\_to\_live), a dictionary that is used to hold custom application specific properties, and a body of string data.
trans-unit.target: Azure::ServiceBus::BrokeredMessage objects have a set of standard properties (such as label and time\_to\_live), a dictionary that is used to hold custom application specific properties, and a body of string data.

trans-unit.source: An application can set the body of the message by passing a string value to the send\_topic\_message() method and any required standard properties will be populated by default values.
trans-unit.target: An application can set the body of the message by passing a string value to the send\_topic\_message() method and any required standard properties will be populated by default values.

trans-unit.source: The following example demonstrates how to send five test messages to "test-topic".
trans-unit.target: The following example demonstrates how to send five test messages to "test-topic".

trans-unit.source: Note that the message_number custom property value of each message varies on the iteration of the loop (this will determine which subscription receive it):
trans-unit.target: Note that the message_number custom property value of each message varies on the iteration of the loop (this will determine which subscription receive it):

trans-unit.source: Service Bus topics support a maximum message size of 256 MB (the header, which includes the standard and custom application properties, can have a maximum size of 64 MB).
trans-unit.target: Service Bus topics support a maximum message size of 256 MB (the header, which includes the standard and custom application properties, can have a maximum size of 64 MB).

trans-unit.source: There is no limit on the number of messages held in a topic but there is a cap on the total size of the messages held by a topic.
trans-unit.target: There is no limit on the number of messages held in a topic but there is a cap on the total size of the messages held by a topic.

trans-unit.source: This topic size is defined at creation time, with an upper limit of 5 GB.
trans-unit.target: This topic size is defined at creation time, with an upper limit of 5 GB.

trans-unit.source: Messages are received from a subscription using the receive\_subscription\_message() method on the Azure::ServiceBusService object.
trans-unit.target: Messages are received from a subscription using the receive\_subscription\_message() method on the Azure::ServiceBusService object.

trans-unit.source: By default, messages are read(peak) and locked without deleting it from the subscription.
trans-unit.target: By default, messages are read(peak) and locked without deleting it from the subscription.

trans-unit.source: You can read and delete the message from the subscription by setting the peek\_lock option to false.
trans-unit.target: You can read and delete the message from the subscription by setting the peek\_lock option to false.

trans-unit.source: The default behavior makes the reading and deleting into a two stage operation, which makes it possible to support applications that cannot tolerate missing messages.
trans-unit.target: The default behavior makes the reading and deleting into a two stage operation, which makes it possible to support applications that cannot tolerate missing messages.

trans-unit.source: When service bus receives a request, it finds the next message to be consumed, locks it to prevent other consumers receiving it, and then returns it to the application.
trans-unit.target: When service bus receives a request, it finds the next message to be consumed, locks it to prevent other consumers receiving it, and then returns it to the application.

trans-unit.source: After the application finishes processing the message (or stores it reliably for future processing), it completes the second stage of the receive process by calling delete\_subscription\_message() method and providing the message to be deleted as a parameter.
trans-unit.target: After the application finishes processing the message (or stores it reliably for future processing), it completes the second stage of the receive process by calling delete\_subscription\_message() method and providing the message to be deleted as a parameter.

trans-unit.source: The delete\_subscription\_message() method will mark the message as being consumed and remove it from the subscription.
trans-unit.target: The delete\_subscription\_message() method will mark the message as being consumed and remove it from the subscription.

trans-unit.source: If the :peek\_lock parameter is set to false, reading and deleting the message becomes the simplest model, and works best for scenarios in which an application can tolerate not processing a message in the event of a failure.
trans-unit.target: If the :peek\_lock parameter is set to false, reading and deleting the message becomes the simplest model, and works best for scenarios in which an application can tolerate not processing a message in the event of a failure.

trans-unit.source: To understand this, consider a scenario in which the consumer issues the receive request and then crashes before processing it.
trans-unit.target: To understand this, consider a scenario in which the consumer issues the receive request and then crashes before processing it.

trans-unit.source: Because Service Bus will have marked the message as being consumed, then when the application restarts and begins consuming messages again, it will have missed the message that was consumed prior to the crash.
trans-unit.target: Because Service Bus will have marked the message as being consumed, then when the application restarts and begins consuming messages again, it will have missed the message that was consumed prior to the crash.

trans-unit.source: The example below demonstrates how messages can be received and processed using receive\_subscription\_message().
trans-unit.target: The example below demonstrates how messages can be received and processed using receive\_subscription\_message().

trans-unit.source: The example first receives and deletes a message from the "low-messages" subscription by using :peek\_lock set to false, then it receives another message from the "high-messages" and then deletes the message using delete\_subscription\_message():
trans-unit.target: The example first receives and deletes a message from the "low-messages" subscription by using :peek\_lock set to false, then it receives another message from the "high-messages" and then deletes the message using delete\_subscription\_message():

trans-unit.source: Service bus provides functionality to help you gracefully recover from errors in your application or difficulties processing a message.
trans-unit.target: Service bus provides functionality to help you gracefully recover from errors in your application or difficulties processing a message.

trans-unit.source: If a receiver application is unable to process the message for some reason, then it can call the unlock\_subscription\_message() method on the Azure::ServiceBusService object.
trans-unit.target: If a receiver application is unable to process the message for some reason, then it can call the unlock\_subscription\_message() method on the Azure::ServiceBusService object.

trans-unit.source: This will cause service bus to unlock the message within the subscription and make it available to be received again, either by the same consuming application or by another consuming application.
trans-unit.target: This will cause service bus to unlock the message within the subscription and make it available to be received again, either by the same consuming application or by another consuming application.

trans-unit.source: There is also a timeout associated with a message locked within the subscription, and if the application fails to process the message before the lock timeout expires (e.g., if the application crashes), then service bus will unlock the message automatically and make it available to be received again.
trans-unit.target: There is also a timeout associated with a message locked within the subscription, and if the application fails to process the message before the lock timeout expires (e.g., if the application crashes), then service bus will unlock the message automatically and make it available to be received again.

trans-unit.source: In the event that the application crashes after processing the message but before the delete\_subscription\_message() method is called, then the message will be redelivered to the application when it restarts.
trans-unit.target: In the event that the application crashes after processing the message but before the delete\_subscription\_message() method is called, then the message will be redelivered to the application when it restarts.

trans-unit.source: This is often called At Least Once Processing, that is, each message will be processed at least once but in certain situations the same message may be redelivered.
trans-unit.target: This is often called At Least Once Processing, that is, each message will be processed at least once but in certain situations the same message may be redelivered.

trans-unit.source: If the scenario cannot tolerate duplicate processing, then application developers should add additional logic to their application to handle duplicate message delivery.
trans-unit.target: If the scenario cannot tolerate duplicate processing, then application developers should add additional logic to their application to handle duplicate message delivery.

trans-unit.source: This is often achieved using the message\_id property of the message, which will remain constant across delivery attempts.
trans-unit.target: This is often achieved using the message\_id property of the message, which will remain constant across delivery attempts.

trans-unit.source: Topics and subscriptions are persistent, and must be explicitly deleted either through the <linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title> or programmatically.
trans-unit.target: Topics and subscriptions are persistent, and must be explicitly deleted either through the <linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title> or programmatically.

trans-unit.source: The example below demonstrates how to delete the topic named "test-topic".
trans-unit.target: The example below demonstrates how to delete the topic named "test-topic".

trans-unit.source: Deleting a topic will also delete any subscriptions that are registered with the topic.
trans-unit.target: Deleting a topic will also delete any subscriptions that are registered with the topic.

trans-unit.source: Subscriptions can also be deleted independently.
trans-unit.target: Subscriptions can also be deleted independently.

trans-unit.source: The following code demonstrates how to delete the subscription named "high-messages" from the "test-topic" topic:
trans-unit.target: The following code demonstrates how to delete the subscription named "high-messages" from the "test-topic" topic:

trans-unit.target: Now that you've learned the basics of Service Bus topics, follow these links to learn more.

trans-unit.target: See the MSDN Reference: <linkText>Queues, Topics, and Subscriptions</linkText><title></title>
